text:
- [Werner] When I grew
up in the Westfjords,

I remember the local
fishermen being the heroes,
the knights in shining armors of the area.

We would see them come in
in their smaller boats,
coming in with salvation.
They were filled with fish.
They were filled with hope.

During the last 40 years,
we had to find new ways

of actually creating
value from our products.

We're seeing innovative
projects in every town.

They show the people there
a new way of creating value

from something that was
considered leftovers.

They might be, for many cases,
the knights in shining armor.
Our planets and our civilizations
are changing faster than ever before.
Join me as I travel the globe,
talking to starter founders
using technologies to make our world
more interesting, accessible, and livable.
These are the entrepreneurs

that are creating the
future we will live in.
This is "Now Go Build."
(upbeat music)
(mellow music)

Iceland is astonishingly
beautiful, but it's also harsh.

It's a severe environment of
lava rock, deep cold water,
and earth-shaking volcanic eruptions.
Winters are dark and long
in this essentially treeless landscape,

yet somehow all these elements
just add to its beauty
and surprisingly, its livability.

In the last century
alone, Iceland has become

one of the most developed
nations in the world,
and with one of the greenest economies.

This is due in large
part to the resourceful

and pragmatic approach
born of living on a volcano
in the middle of the North Atlantic.
For over a thousand years,
these descendants of Norse Vikings
have evolved their way of living
on this sparsely inhabited island.
With a waste-nothing approach

that uses scarce natural
resources in novel ways,
Iceland's startups are inspiring ingenuity

in the country's tech
landscape and beyond.
They've also inspired my visit here
to see how AWS can help support
their development and growth.
What can we learn from a country
that celebrates such inventive efficiency?
The waters that surround Iceland

are some of the healthiest
natural fisheries on the planet,
and here in Isafjordur, in the Westfjords,

Fertram Sigurjonsson has
discovered a highly innovative use

of what was once a waste
product of the fishing industry,

healing the wounded with
the skin of Atlantic Cod.

Fertram, pleasure meeting you.
- Hi.
- Thanks for having me here.
- Welcome.
- Thank you. Let visit Kerecis.
- Awesome, this way.

- [Werner] Tell me what
are we seeing here?

- We take fish skins from
the fish processing plant
and we make a medical product out of it.
So grafts, these are grafts
that are used for wounds and for surgery.

In Iceland, we have a
very big fishing industry.
The fish is brought to port
and it goes into the fish processing.

The filets are created and
the filets and deskinned.
Normally, the skins are thrown away

and we make our medical
product out of the fish skin.
I was working with a prosthetic company

and I just witnessed
this incredible problem
that all the customers of that company,

they have been amputated
because of diabetic wounds.

So we were thinking about
how can we create a material
that actually can heal those wounds
so there aren't so many amputations.
- Okay.

- And what happens is that
the doctor gets our material
and he has a giant wound
that has not responded to treatment,
might be a diabetic patient,
it might be someone with a big burn wound.
And the doctor takes a knife

and he cuts away all the
dead tissue from the wound
and he makes the wound bleeding.

Then he takes our material and
puts it into the wound bed,

and then he puts the
wound dressing on top.
And what happens is that the human cells,

they will start to crawl
into the fish skin,
and they think that they're at home.
They think they're in the human body,
but they see a lot of holes.
And they say, oh, we need to crawl in
and reoccupy, refill those holes
and start to make new tissue.

And over time, the fish skin
is remodeled to human skin
over two or three weeks.

And we've been doing this
now here for five years.

And we treated this year
more than 10,000 patients.
(gentle music)
(speaker speaks foreign language)

- So we get the fish skin
from the fish factory,
then we descale it,

and then we take the
skins into this room here

and the skins are decelled
in this facility here.

So if we have the fish
skin with fish cells in it

and we put it into wound, the
body would go on an alarm.
There's fish DNA. You would get allergies.

So, here we are actually
removing the cells
in a very gentle, proprietary manner.
- [Werner] So what's left then?

- It's collagen, fats,
hyaluronic acid, laminin,
all sorts of very complicated structure,

three dimensional structure.
- But no cells.
- No cells, yeah.
And then when we've extracted the cells
we have the fish skin like this here,

but full of tiny holes,
like a scaffold or template.
- [Werner] Okay.
What are we seeing here?

- So here people are removing
the fascia from the fish skin
and they're scraping it off.
So you see, there are flesh rests.
We don't want any flesh rests on them
because there's a molecule in the flesh
that causes physiology,
so you want to get rid of the flesh rests.

And the next step after
this is quality inspection,

and that's where we're using
artificial intelligence.
And the problem with quality inspection
is that there are so many specimen
that the humans, they lose their attention
because there are so few errors.
There is one scale on every 1500th piece.
- Oh yeah.
- And when you're inspecting 1500 pieces,

you lose your focus and actually
you miss that 1500th, too.
(upbeat music)
- [Werner] As with any innovation,

bringing new concepts and
products to market at scale

without sacrificing quality
is always a challenge,

especially when there
is no margin for error.

When one errant cell
can result in disaster,
quality control is essential,
a problem well suited for machine learning

and a problem easily solved
with support from AWS.
Pleasure meeting you, man.

So, what else do you guys
do here with technology?

- We are working currently
on trying to automate
a few of our manufacturing processes.
You saw at our other facility,

we do all of our scraping
where we are cleaning fascia

and flash remains from
inside of the skins?
- [Werner] Yeah.

- [Baldur] We want to
automate that a little bit
to include computer vision
and assist the staff for quality control.
- And so do you make use of, let's say,

the standard ML techniques,
like your recognition,
or do you develop your own algorithms?

- We are developing
convolution neural networking.
- Okay.

- To analyze the images,
we are really relying
on cloud computing for this task.
- Yeah.
- And it needs to happen pretty quickly.

- Plus, that you now
suddenly have evidence
of what happened for them to process,

where it's harder for
humans to sort of write down
this is what I was looking at.
- Yeah, yeah.

- Things become facts
instead of intuition.
- Yeah.
(bright music)
- [Werner] Atlantic Cod is not the only
abundant resource in Iceland.
There are massive amounts of fresh water

stored in some of the most
impressive glaciers on the planet
and an incredible amount of volcanic heat
coursing through geologic layers

upon which the Icelanders
have built their homes.
The country is powered almost entirely
by hydropower and geothermal power,

but even with these
natural sources of energy,
there's a potential for waste.

In true Icelandic form,
Nanom, here in Reykjavik

is using the cloud to
collect and analyze data

that will not only help
mitigate this waste,

but also revolutionize the
storage of renewable energy.
Hey, Armann.
- [Armann] Welcome.
- Thank you. Thanks for having me here.
99% of the batteries at this moment
in the world are lithium ion.
- Yeah, yeah.
- But you guys are departing from that.

So, tell us a bit about
what Nanom is doing.

- So, Nanom is creating
these breakthrough materials
that enable batteries to last longer,
have a longer cycle life
to be more environmentally friendly.
And we basically have building blocks
for the batteries of today,
which where we put our nanoparticles
inside of lithium ion batteries

to kind of reduce the amount
of materials that go in there
to increase the efficiency.

But we're also using these
breakthrough materials
to build the products of tomorrow.
Because if you think about it,

the ultimate battery is
having no battery at all.
(bright music)

- [Werner] Let's go back to
the beginning, nanoparticles.
- [Armann] Yes, yes.
- Tell us what we should envision
when we think about a nanoparticle.
- Well, it's one billionth of a meter.
If I take a little, thin business card,
that's 100,000 nanometers thick,

and actually a business card
is a good way to describe it

because I have the front
of the business card
and the back of the business card,
and we kind of understand the surface area
of something we're looking at.
But if I now cut that into 100,000 layers,
I have so much surface area to work with
and I can create several football fields.

So, now what's happening
inside of a battery

is there's an interaction
between the materials.

- So the particles basically
create a big ion membrane.
- Yes. Yeah, yeah.

All of a sudden you have more
space to work with, more area,
and it sort of changes the dynamics
of what you have in your hands.

Thomas Edison invented the
battery over a hundred years ago.
He put it in a car, it had good range,

and it was a very
environmentally friendly battery.

The only drawback was
that it was very heavy

and it was kind of
insufficient to produce.
- Yeah.

- But if you can replace
these larger battery plates

with nanoparticles, carbon
fiber, special electrolyte,
you are just reshaping

what an environmentally
friendly battery can do.
- So the red ones are your...

- These are the Edisons, yeah.
- The Edisons.

- And you can see the bigger
white one is the original one.
The plates themselves are, you know,
these are the original ones
and we're doing it with this instead.
So like, this is the difference
in the way you kind of approach it
and this is how much it weighs

compared to like several
of these together.
- Yeah, yeah, yeah.
It's amazing.
- It's like a game changer in that aspect.

- Yeah, but you can imagine
that if your batteries,
which are now a very large part
of the weight of a car or an airplane,
if you can reduce the weight of that,

it's a significant winner
in terms of energy use.
I understand you're also working

with traditional energy
companies like here in Iceland.
- Yeah, yeah, yeah.

- So they are looking
for long term storage
of their geothermal energy.
- Yeah, what's interesting is
that the problem the world has right now
is not really capturing renewable energy.
It's storing it.

And you know, like geothermal,
it goes 24/7 obviously.

We made these little modular
units that you can take
if you wanna power your house,

you serial parallel connect
them like Lego blocks
for your house,
but if you want the geothermal plant,
you just use more units

and you increase the
amount of these cells.

- And of course the storage of
energy is a generic problem.
- It's a generic problem, yes.
- And it's not just unique for Iceland,
but the technologies that you develop here
will be applicable anywhere
regardless of what the energy source is.
- [Armann] Exactly.
(soft music)
This is ON Energy.
This is Berglind.

- Oh, hi.
- Oh, hi.
- I'm Werner. Pleasure meeting you.
- Thanks for having us here.
- We operate a combined heat

and power geothermal station
producing electricity

for the whole island and hot
water for the Reykjavik area.
- [Armann] Iceland's an interesting place
because we transformed this whole country
by getting access to renewable energy

and kind of realizing what
we had in our own backyard.

- Yes, we are blessed with
natural resources here in Iceland

and we produce electricity
using hydropower.

Around 70% of the
electricity produced here

is produced harnessing the
energy from waterfalls.

And then the 30% is produced
using geothermal resources.
This is what we do at ON Power.
We are mainly a geothermal company

and we produce around
20% of the electricity
produced in Iceland.

- So hydro power combined
with geothermal power

basically covers 100%
of the electricity usage
here in Iceland.
- Yes, 100%. Yeah.
So the steam comes from underground

and is transferred to the
power plant through pipes.
And then very hot steam is input in here.
And then this steam is used
to generate rotation in the turbines.

And then the electricity
flows from here to the grid
and then to the users.
- It's actually an interesting process
because you go from heat to kinetic energy
to electrical energy.
- Exactly. Yeah, yeah.
And we use also,

because it's a combined
heat and power plant,

so when they use the steam
to generate electricity,
it cools down and turns into hot water.

And then the hot water, we use
the heat up the cold water.
And then we've utilized the steam twice.
(bright music)
- [Werner] With traditional power plants,
the fossil fuel ones,
you can turn them up and turn them down
based on what the expected usage is.

But I mean, you can't turn
your power source off here,
or less or more.

So, what are the big
challenges around that?
- Yes. Yeah, that is true.
It's called base load power

and they basically produce the
same amount of electricity,
you know, every hour of the year.
And this can be a challenge
because the demand for electricity

is higher during the day
than during the night.

- But then storage of the
energy that you produce

and that is not immediately
being distributed
must be very important parts.

What kind of techniques do
you use to store the energy?
- So, when you are producing hydropower,

so you have a waterfall
and you have a reservoir.

The reservoir basically
acts like a battery.
It's an energy storage.

In geothermal power plants,
we don't have a reservoir
and it can happen that when demand is low,

and maybe a little bit
lower than our production,
there's waste created in the system.
Battery storage is one of the technologies
that could help us solve this.
(light music)

- So we heard earlier when
we talked about hydropower

that basically the basin
of water is the buffer.

So what would be an
ideal buffer for thermal?
- Yeah, I mean, any battery you look at,

whether it's in an
electric car or a laptop,
it's all modular.
It's all many units coming together.
So the more that you can create units

that modularly come
together in an easy way,

the closer you are to
tackling any energy problem,
whether it's a huge one or a small one.

The abundance, the sheer
volume of what's going on here,
is the really exciting stuff

'cause that mirrors
potential for the world.
- Yeah, and of course here,

weight maybe doesn't necessarily
matter that terribly much.

- Yeah, I mean, here it's
about not wasting material

because you have a really
environmentally friendly battery
but it kind of crosses the threshold

of being really usable
if it's too expensive
and if you're depleting the planet
of the raw materials to make it.

So if you can get that
efficiency in a smaller unit,
then all of a sudden you have this

environmentally friendly,
50,000 cycle capacity battery
that is very well paired with geothermal
and sustainable energy sources.
(bright music)
- So if you talk about a cell,

that still sounds like a
traditional form factor.
- Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah.

- One of the things that
you guys are working on
is on different types of form factors.

- If you start really
thinking outside the box,
you're no longer tied to lithium

and you're no longer tied to
putting it inside of this unit

but you start decentralizing
the energy source

and you start making up
the layers of the battery
together with other materials.

So we take carbon fiber and
nanoparticles and we make that.
It looks and feels like a carbon fiber.

You can shape it the way
that you shape carbon fiber

but because of the nanoparticles
that are hidden within it,
it becomes a battery plate.
The idea is that you fit this
into the way things are manufactured.

So what if you were building
an electric motorbike
or something out of carbon fiber
and what if that could become the battery?
You would build it the same way
but you would set it up as a battery.
And if you puncture this, it still works.

And it doesn't heat up
when you're charging it.

So the things we're used to
a battery doing that are bad,

this doesn't really kind
of go into that territory.

The key is to kind of
distribute it in larger objects
and the better that the technology gets,

the smaller the object is
that you can sort of disrupt.
So you start with the bigger fishing boats
or boats are actually ideal

because there's so much
space in the structure.
- [Werner] But your approach...

I mean, if you build
your boat as a battery,

you can't throw your battery
away after two years.
- No, no, exactly.

And when we talk to people that
are building these products,

what you realize is the best
way to bring it to the market
is actually to do a mix and match
where you use a structural battery
along with a regular battery.

And then the structural battery
takes all the short trips
and the fast charging,

and you triple the lifetime
of the lithium ion.
And then, the stronger your battery gets,
eventually you'll design the product,

the whole product around
the structural battery.
(lighthearted music)

- So tell us a bit how compute
and data and data processing

and analytics plays a role
in your development process.

- Yeah, it's actually
the key to everything

because the starting
point is our materials
and we need to understand

what type of materials
we have in our hands
and we need to be able

to reproduce those
materials in the same way

when they give good
results on the other side.
So we're analyzing nanoparticles

but we're also trying to
hypothesize what would happen

if we mix together different
types of materials,
or if we go down in size
from 100 nanometers to 50 nanometers.
There's so many factors changing

and then we're collecting all
that data and analyzing that.
Then, when you're looking at something
like a new type of battery,
you don't have any historical data.

The first question
somebody's gonna ask you
is how many cycle lifes does it have.

Well, the I'm sorry but the
battery is only two months old.
I don't have 10 years of data.

So then you need to also
hypothesize what would happen there

and any tweak that you make
inside of these products,
you're trying to figure that out.
(mellow music)

- And so, if I look
out for the past years,

there's probably been
thousands of companies

that have tried to tackle the
problem that you are tackling.
The majority of those have not succeeded.

So why do you think that
you will be succeeding
where the other ones failed?
- There's a lot of labs all over the world
that have put nanotechnology into products
but it's kind of of no use to no one,
if you have just a million dollar battery
that you can't sort of move out of the lab
and into the product.
Our starting point was the fact

that we invented this novel
way, using a lot of methods,
including a particle accelerator,

to actually create massive
amounts of nanoparticles
which is really relevant to just kind of

getting it out of the
lab and into production.
What makes us unique is the fact
that we can adjust our methods

to all these different
battery chemistries.

So we're not betting on
one type of nanomaterial
that is gonna save the world.

We're using a method for
accessing the attributes
of all these materials

and working with partners
that already know
that certain things work

and we're giving them like a
super layer on top of that,
that makes things more efficient.
The timing seems to be good right now
because we're all aware of the importance
of changing how we do things.

Iceland is a great place
to run with things,
to test things out, to validate things.

What the silicon chip
did for Silicon Valley,
nano can do for Iceland.
We can start a new story from here.
(peaceful music)

- [Werner] The natural
resources that Iceland has used

to become one of the greenest
economies on the planet

are not readily available
to the rest of us.
Some of us are landlocked

or lack geothermal
energy to run our cities.

This country is as unique
as I've ever visited.
So what can we learn from them?

Possibly the lesson here is
to look in our own backyards.
What do we have at our disposal?
What are we wasting?

How can we use modern
technological advances,

such as the cloud, to
increase our own efficiencies
and unlock new ways of living and working?
Maybe Iceland's greatest export

will be its approach to living
with its natural resources.

Lessons forged in a
thousand endless winters
on a rock in the middle of the Atlantic,
may just be the kind of thinking we need
to live in balance on Earth.
(gentle music)
